docs.title: Welcome to CacheMatic
docs.text:
We are working hard to deliver high-quality documentation to you as soon as possible.

Stay tuned!

In the meantime, check out our socials KU Leuven eMedia Research Lab, MERL-UIT and GitHub

docs.title: Architecture
docs.text: TODO: showcase how CacheMatic is designed and what are its primary principles.

docs.title: Getting started
docs.text: You've done the Chisel Bootcamp, and now you are ready to start your own Chisel project. The following procedure should get you started with a clean running Chisel3 project.

docs.title: JDK 11 or newer
docs.text: We recommend using Java 11 or later LTS releases. While Chisel itself works with Java 8, our preferred build tool Mill requires Java 11. You can install the JDK as your operating system recommends, or use the prebuilt binaries from Adoptium (formerly AdoptOpenJDK).

docs.title: SBT or mill
docs.text: SBT is the most common build tool in the Scala community. You can download it here. Mill is another Scala/Java build tool preferred by Chisel's developers. This repository includes a bootstrap script ./mill so that no installation is necessary. You can read more about Mill on its website: https://mill-build.org.

docs.title: Verilator
docs.text: The test with svsim needs Verilator installed. See Verilator installation instructions here.

docs.title: Create a repository from the template
docs.text: This repository is a Github template. You can create your own repository from it by clicking the green Use this template in the top right. Please leave Include all branches unchecked; checking it will pollute the history of your new repository. For more information, see "Creating a repository from a template".

docs.title: Wait for the template cleanup workflow to complete
docs.text: After using the template to create your own blank project, please wait a minute or two for the Template cleanup workflow to run which will removes some template-specific stuff from the repository (like the LICENSE). Refresh the repository page in your browser until you see a 2nd commit by actions-user titled Template cleanup.

docs.title: Clone your repository
docs.text:
Once you have created a repository from this template and the Template cleanup workflow has completed, you can click the green button to get a link for cloning your repository. Note that it is easiest to push to a repository if you set up SSH with Github, please see the related documentation. SSH is required for pushing to a Github repository when using two-factor authentication.

git clone git@github.com:merledu/CacheMatic.git
cd CacheMatic

docs.title: Set project organization and name in build.sbt
docs.text: The cleanup workflow will have attempted to provide sensible defaults for ThisBuild / organization and name in the build.sbt. Feel free to use your text editor of choice to change them as you see fit.

docs.title: Clean up the README.md file
docs.text: Again, use you editor of choice to make the README specific to your project.

docs.title: Add a LICENSE file
docs.text:
It is important to have a LICENSE for open source (or closed source) code. This template repository has the Unlicense in order to allow users to add any license they want to derivative code. The Unlicense is stripped when creating a repository from this template so that users do not accidentally unlicense their own work.

For more information about a license, check out the Github Docs.

docs.title: Commit your changes
docs.text:
git commit -m 'Starting CacheMatic'
git push origin main

docs.title: Did it work?
docs.text:
You should now have a working Chisel3 project.

You can run the included test with: 

sbt test

Alternatively, if you use Mill: 

./mill CacheMatic.test

You should see a whole bunch of output that ends with something like the following lines 

[info] Tests: succeeded 1, failed 0, canceled 0, ignored 0, pending 0
[info] All tests passed.
[success] Total time: 5 s, completed Dec 16, 2020 12:18:44 PM
If you see the above then...

docs.title: It worked!
docs.text:
You are ready to go. We have a few recommended practices and things to do.

  • Use packages and following conventions for structure and naming
  • Package names should be clearly reflected in the testing hierarchy
  • Build tests for all your work
  • Read more about testing in SBT in the SBT docs
  • This template includes a test dependency on ScalaTest. This, coupled with svsim (included with Chisel) and verilator, are a starting point for testing Chisel generators.
  • You can remove this dependency in the build.sbt file if you want to
  • Change the name of your project in the build.sbt file
  • Change your README.md

docs.title: Problems? Questions?
docs.text: Check out the Chisel Users Community page for links to get in contact!

docs.title: Changelog
docs.text:
All notable changes to this project will be documented in this file.

The format is based on Keep a Changelog.

This project adheres to Semantic Versioning.

docs.title: 0.0.1 Month Day, Year
docs.text: • Initial publically available version of the subsystem.
